threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9411297
America had the same problem and was really strong about it in the 80s and 90s. Every new big pop culture trend was a sign of the devil to these people. D&D was an early one, but everything from Barney and Pokemon to Arthur and Harry Potter was supposedly going to make your kids into gay satanists. I have known so many people that had to fight with their parents to be allowed to play Zelda because their parents thought it was some retarded witchcraft thing.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9417412
That was a thing, but it wasn't a universal thing.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9417418
I didn't mean to say it was universal, just that it existed and it was similar. I doubt that the anon I quoted was implying that everyone in the country was hunting down and destroying supposedly sacrilegious games in the name of Jesus, baptizing any babies and manchildren they found on their way. Likewise, I was not implying universality either, just that it was a cultural undertone. You'd have people who made a career out of claiming that this or that was evil and satanic, and that your children needed God and Jesus and yadda yadda yadda. You had people that formed parent groups which aimed to stop the production of things they thought were subversive, whether it was D&D manuals or Twisted Sister albums. The US actually has a much longer history of religious revivals and fervor than I am experienced enough to comment on, but in terms of pop culture, the energy has been a slow but consistent undercurrent especially in more conservative areas. In terms of pop culture, you had things like the Beatles album burnings in the 60s after they said they were bigger than Jesus, but those were more like isolated incidents to the public eye. The late 20th century brought the proliferation of cable TV, VHS tapes by mail, and trashy talk shows/late night TV weirdos, which really allowed it to spread further and to cover more topics. And maybe it's just that I grew up in a conservative area, but I happened to see or know a number of people who dealt with this when growing up. Hell, even now I still meet people who had these experiences growing up, and I'm not even in a conservative area anymore.
Again not saying it was universal, but it definitely got around.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
The last 3 undumped commercial SNES games.

Mortal Kombat (EU)(v1.2) - "##B" stamp on back, "-2" on ROM chip or "9616" date code or higher on any chip
Derby Stallion II (JP)(v1.1) - "##A" stamp, "-1" ROM or "9441"+ date
Igo Club (JP)(v1.1) - "##A" stamp, "-1" ROM or "9624" to "9818" date

https://mobile.twitter.com/nointro_org/status/1581569532472496128

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9416356
>>9416483
There's no evidence that these revisions were ever released, though. There's a few games on the lotcheck lists that never came out.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9416510
Even if we're talking just retro consoles, there were some that had undefeated protections at the time. Like the 3DO, which used 512-bit RSA signatures in 1993.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9416959
Looking at the SNES lotcheck spreadsheet:
>Igo Club Rev 1:
>Revision content: Fixed a problem that occurred when the computer was thinking in the game mode. ROM output cancellation.
>Derby Stallion 2 Rev 1
>Contents of the revision: If you receive a temporary horse riding request event and perform follow-up training, it will hang up.
Mortal Kombat(PAL) has a 2nd revision listed, but the comments are just "SPAL-KX-2 P0 (1B69h) SPAL-KX-2 P1 (B439h)". Which is different than the values listed for the first two versions, but no reason is given for the difference. Igo club isn't really a big deal since they already have Rev 2 dumped which would also have that fix, but it's there for the sake of completion. Derby Stallion 2 and Mortal Kombat PAL Rev 2 are the important ones, since there aren't any later revisions. Given most companies just wanted to move on to the next game, a revision wouldn't exist unless a bug needed to be fixed. With Derby Stallion 2, that's a game-freezing bug. MK could be any number of issues.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: 5th console generation was the real golden age
threads.com:
People often say that 4th gen was the golden age, specifically SNES, because, because 2D matured enough to look good, while 5th gen was the period of experimentation and early 3D and thus did not age well. In fact, this is correct only for side scrolling platformer games. Genre by genre, 5th gen was the period when many genres, which were miserable during 4th gen, finally became great.
>Fighting games.
4th gen only had Street Fighter 2 ports which are still good. All other fighting games were compromised in various ways and are hard to get back to. Mortal Kombat, World Heroes, Art of Fighting, Fatal Fury - these were okayish 7.5/10 in arcades but home ports sucked big time with possible exception of SNES MK2. You didn't have great fighting experience on home consoles.
On 5th gen you have literal masterpieces like VF2, Tekken 2 and 3, SF Alpha games and other Capcom and SNK ports. Even on PS1, which is considered less desireable than Saturn for 2D fighting games, things like SFA or Real Bout shit all over any of the SNES or Genesis ports.
>Racing games
This is even easier. Daytona USA, Ridge Racer, Sega Rally, Gran Turismo, Need for Speed - these all are huge system sellers and still play great. SNES and Genesis have tons of racing games but they all are shovelware. Nothing on the level and prominence of the titles mentioned above. Out Run was good only on arcades.
>First person shooters
5th gen had Doom, Quake and Goldeneye. Nuff said. SNES Doom is more of a curiosity than a proper game. 16 bit consoles only had Wolfenstein and Zero Tolerance which is a Wolfenstein clone - both very simplistic and flat, compared to Doom.
>Real Time Strategy
There is Dune 2 on Genesis and that's it. Herzog Zwei is a strategy/shmup hybrid and is a different genre. Dune 2 is a very barebones game with only skirmish missions, bad controls and tons of slowdown. 5th gen consoles have proper RTS games with C&C, Red Alert and Warcraft 2 ports.

I like 5th gen anyway, but nah I think 4th gen was the real golden age of home systems.

Lady Stalker (SNES) exists because they felt they were snubbed by Sega, and Dark Savior (Saturn) exists because they made up but is only a shadow of its former self despite being billed as the evolution of Landstalker, and Time Stalkers is a generic 3D JRPG billed as a crossover, and Steel Princess (DS) is the only major time they revisited Landstalker's gameplay outside of the ill-fated PSP remake. Then they went defunct.

Climax had some staff exodus, and they founded Matrix Software. They did Alundra, published by Sony. It's largely a one-off game, and a sequel happened that had little to do with it.
There was some more staff exodus to Epics, and they did Popolocrois Monogatari, which is very similar to Landstalker. They continued, and the team is still together as late as 2020.

The tragedy behind Landstalker is that the talent and IP was scattered across multiple companies, and as time passed the isometric style and detailed pixel art quickly fell out of relevance then.

last_replies.com:
>>9416618
TVL is the number of discrete vertical lines the mask can resolve in a span of horizontal length equivalent to the vertical length of the tube - in other words, within the area of a square that starts at the leftmost edge of the tube. Since we're not working with a square picture, it isn't exactly equivalent to horizontal resolution.

In an emulated CRT, assuming the image isn't letterboxed from integer scaling, TVL is effectively calculated by dividing the panel's vertical resolution by the number of pixels used to draw a complete phosphor triad. So for instance, if we're using a mask such as RGBX (Mask 10 in Guest's shaders), which uses four pixels horizontally to draw each phosphor triad, at 1440p we'd do 1440 / 4 = 360. If you desire lower TVL, you'd have to use a custom mask pattern that uses more pixels (Sony Megatron has patterns that use up to 7).

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Whenever I'm looking through libraries of old games for something play I always wonder what happened to all the dead IPs. There used to be so much more variety back then, with big and small budget titles for every console. Some experimental, others trying revolutionize their own genre.
Nowadays you only ever see the famous long-lived companies releasing new games for the same 4~5 franchises they own, naturally because those survived the test of time, and the test of "how much money can we keep making with them".
In some cases they even refuse to acknowledge the existence of certain games that they've developed or published simply because they never sold well enough when competition was fierce, and are only remembered when someone makes a list of fun games of a specific genre for X or Y console. Forgotten Worlds, Captain Commando, Dirt Dash, Gradius, Bloody Roar, Comix Zone, Smashing Drive, all those other arcade machines and third party ventures that barely got two paragraphs worth of a description on Wikipedia, that only amounted to a sporadic "hey remember playing this game?" here or there.

It's just business of course, but I always end up wondering if videogames as a whole have only ever been a process of trimming the wheat from the chaff until you have a couple of golden eggs all along, and if all but the few most profitable titles are gone forever.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
>...the Commodore 264 line, intended by Jack Tramiel as a low cost competitor to the ZX Spectrum, got turned after his termination from Commodore in summer 1984 into something else other than what he intended. The Plus/4 was a sort of productivity computer with the C16 and Europe-only C116 as low end entries. The 264 line quickly flopped in the US market but proved relatively successful in Europe. The sound was limited compared to the C64's SID chip and there were no hardware sprites; as a tradeoff the Plus/4 had more colors (121 total) and hardware text blinking along with a faster CPU (1.7Mhz against the C64's 1.2Mhz) and a better, more fully-featured BASIC interpreter.

>The 264 line also suffered from reliability issues. The CPU and graphics chip, the TED, were made with the newer 3.5 micrometer HMOS process rather than the old 5 micrometer NMOS process used in the C64 chipset. MOS struggled to get the new process to work reliably; it had been used in the C64 PLA chip which suffered a high failure rate. According to Commodore engineer Bil Herd, the doping process used was flawed and would result in a runaway thermal effect and chip failure. Consequently, failed TED chips became a frequent problem in the Plus/4.

>The Plus/4 was not a major success but the C16, which was more reliable overall, sold decently in Europe as a low cost home/gaming computer despite its scant (for 1985) RAM size (16k with 11k usable for software).

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
there are a couple things you can do to improve Plus/4's reliability.

>replace CPU with newer model 8501 which runs cooler
>heat sink TED
>replace PLA with modern FPGA replacement
>replace ROMs with modern EEPROMs as these run a lot cooler and draw less power
>do not use autofire joystick unless properly buffered or it will damage the latch on the TED
>remove 3-in-1 ROM as it's useless and you'll reduce power use/heat output a small amount

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
>Gadget is hard to describe. Surreal and unsettling would be a good place to start. A weird curio from a bygone era? Yep. An avant-garde art piece? Yeah, probably that too. I'm hesitant to call it a good game, because it's barely a game at all, but I'll certainly say this... it's interesting.

>The game is extremely linear, mostly shuffling you around from location to location with a few things in any given environment to interact with and, once you do, you'll be shuffled off to the next area. This has the effect, intended or not, of making you feel rather uncomfortable as you're given virtually no control over anything. Practically every game amounts to simply doing what the developers intended, but it's rarely as on the nose as it is here, to the point that it feels less like exerting your own will and intellect to reach a desired conclusion that was planned by the developers and more like doing what they want, regardless of what you want. The distinction is arguably superficial but, in this case, it's palpable just the same.

>Graphically the game is a strange mishmash of steampunk, art deco, and some kind of unidentified Eastern Bloc country aesthetic. Things frequently take a turn for the surreal, and you often travel from one location to the next in something approximating an out of body experience - you'll be looking at a monitor of something and then suddenly move through the monitor into that location, for example.

>Adding to the surreal and unsettling quality is a fantastic, otherworldly soundtrack by Koji Ueno. It sometimes reminded me of the work of Akira Yamaoka, with things frequently turning into walls of abstract industrial noise. If the bizarre visuals and storytelling aren't enough to make you uneasy, the music ought to do the trick.

https://www.zombs-lair.com/gadget-collection

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: >Gadget: Invention, Travel, & Adventure (or Gadget: Past as Future) is an adventure game designed by Haruhiko Shono and first released by Synergy Interactive in 1993, following his earlier works Alice: An Interactive Museum (1991) and L-Zone (1992). Like Shono's earlier titles, Gadget uses pre-rendered 3D computer graphics and resembles a point-and-click adventure game similar to Myst (1993), but with a strictly linear storyline culminating in a fixed finale. It thus sometimes tends to be classified more as an interactive movie rather than a video game. The story centers around a future dominated by retro technology from the 1920s and 1930s, especially streamlined locomotives and flying machines.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: >Developed by Japanese studio Synergy Inc., GADGET: Invention, Travel, & Adventure lacks much of the mechanical structure we associate with games. There is little meaningful interactivity. But because the experience is so un-game-like, so rigid and suffocating, it evokes genuine confusion, terror, and discomfort. This is not a game that will make you jump, but once you’re deep within GADGET‘s pseudo-Soviet web of intrigue and conspiracy, some gut reaction will tell you that it should not be happening.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: >The game's plot takes place in an unspecified (albeit vaguely Eastern European) nation headed by the dictator Orlovsky. The protagonist is a government agent tasked with discovering the whereabouts of a missing scientist named Horselover Frost. He begins his quest in a third-floor room of a luxury hotel (which is in fact the headquarters of the government's intelligence arm). After collecting his belongings in a suitcase, the protagonist takes an elevator ride to the lobby, during which a boy replaces the case with another identical one containing various spy-related paraphernalia. In the lobby, the government's intelligence chief briefs the protagonist on his mission. The protagonist then moves to the central railway station. From this point on all the events of the story take place on trains or at the various stations (which include the national science institute) along the nation's main rail line. The player must engage in scripted conversations with various individuals, each of whom reveals pieces of information that advance the protagonist in his quest.

Behold, the Bandai wonderswan. The superior 90s handheld that deserves far more credit than it receives

With a library matching the Dreamcast in number and variety, it’s 200 games cover genres that portable gaming frankly sucked at beforehand.

Here you’ll find some of the best strategy RPGs and fighters handhelds ever had to offer in 99.

Backed by the powerhouse that was square, the console got a lot of big name titles from the developer. Final fantasies, mystery dungeons, and a fucking clock tower- the selection of quality RPGs on the console kicks the shit out of what the gameboy color and NGPC was offering that same year.

Being the first handheld with a widescreen, it made real nice for fighting games and vertical puzzlers.

From pocket fighter to guilty gear, to digimon and one piece, the system has a healthy selection of fun brawlers that play very well on the small screen.

On the note of one piece, the console was notable for its anime tie ins. Bandai was a licensing powerhouse after all.

The system was quite capable too! Handily shitting all over the cpus of the gameboy and neo geo pocket- this was the only system of the 3 that could run a full ass web browser.

Nearly the entire library runs at 75 fps. Why? Idk but it’s quite nice. Games are smooth with lots of animation and fast clean scrolling. Hundreds of sprites dotting the screen without hiccup.
The system is no slouch in audio hardware either. Having a capable synth setup, AND cool ass sample capabilities- it has a sound that when used to full potential reminds me of some neo geo titles.

Despite the device being a properly capable 16 bit handheld for the time, the thing SIPS power. A single AA battery will keep the thing in active gameplay for well over 40 hours. That’s not 40 hours standby- that’s 40 hours of straight gameplay. On ONE battery. Gbc could barely muster 10 on 2 of the things.
This was also a console that only cost about $30 on release.

threads.com:
It’s the good kind of grindy guys I swear.

The World Series gets shit on a bit for being totally different from each other. Which is true in the PlayStation sense, it’s not like these are the only games of their kind.

World 1 was followed up with numerous future games that follow the same style of Vpet RPG

World 2 has the battle and evolution system that was used for the wonder swan duology/trilogy/there’s a 4th game but it doesn’t count

And world 3 is
Admittedly world 3 is its own thing that was never expanded upon.

World 2 imo is the best of these 3 formulas. And deserves more attention. It’s a very cool mystery dungeon style game. It’s major flaw being fucking insane loading times. But those are mitigated by playing in an emu or something.

Definitely a worthy game for anyone who likes dungeon crawlers, and bespoke monster collectors that aren’t blatant Pokémon clones.

Personally, I’ve been enjoying the absolute fucking hell that is the grind in this game. Very fun 10/10

Plus any nihongonians can play the superior jp version of the game with pocket station support

threads.com:
I just realized something that is a very big mark against Shenmue for me, even as a fan. The game aims to be realistic, so clearly that means that you won't be fighting every 30 seconds like its a Yakuza game, however, because of the lack of fighting it feels as if I never have the chance to get good at the actual combat. I noticed that every battle feels like me testing out moves to see if they work, like I'm fumbling around in practice mode in a fighting game, I never feel like I have the hang of this games fighting mechanics. Its not as if I lose the fights, but its never very satisfying because once I try and fail to be technical and thoughtful with my attack selection, I just default to mashing, regroup, and win anyway.

Perhaps its just me but it feels like a profound revelation right now.

Shenmue's budget being "80 million dollars" isn't really accurate since the game's engine was essentially used as a testbed for a ton of different graphical and technical effects that would find their way into different Sega game engines in Saturn and Dreamcast games. Similar to how Valve continuously pumps time and money into the Source Engine and the resulting features find their way into multiple games (or at least they did, back when Valve actually made videogames).

tl;dr - all of the work and budget that went into Shenmue's development wasn't solely there for Shenmue.

threads.com: What was your reaction when you discovered emulation and ROMsites full of games you'd always wanted to try? What was the first system/game you emulated? I've realised that for some reason when people learn about emulation the first thing they do is play their favorite games instead of trying something new

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9393536

>What was your reaction when you discovered emulation and ROMsites full of games you'd always wanted to try?

Like discovering fire. Imagine all those games from the system you did not own, and come to the realization that you could now play them.

> What was the first system/game you emulated? I've realised that for some reason when people learn about emulation the first thing they do is play their favorite games instead of trying something new

The first thing I emulated was the first thing that was available to me: Mega drive with Bloodlust Software's Genecyst. I went straight to the thing that the console wars told me it was "cooler:" Sonic 2

Truth to be told, Getting a cd with roms in the pre-internet times feels a bit different. It's more like you have been handed an archeological treasure that is "unique" (Did not have a cd writer, losing it would have been bad). Like someone did the Silk Route and brought you that from afar.

As for actually finding rom sites when i had dial-up internet for the first time, it was not great. A lot of the stuff was hosted on sites like Metropoli2000. Once they introduced a queue to download system in 2002, the good times were over. It would take a few more years for Emuparadise and Planetemu to appear.
